title: 109_s4014
content: The NATO Freedom Consolidation Act of 2006 may be cited as such. The NATO Freedom Consolidation Act of 2006 acknowledges NATO's role in promoting democracy in Central and Eastern Europe and emphasizes the importance of integrating emerging democracies into European structures for lasting stability. NATO is recognized for its contribution to global security amidst threats like terrorism and weapons of mass destruction. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 and the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 called for the admission of certain countries to NATO to enhance security in the North Atlantic area. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 emphasized the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in NATO, not limited to Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. The European Security Act of 1998 further supported this by stating that Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria should also be considered for NATO membership. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 highlighted the significance of incorporating emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe into NATO, including Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. The Gerald B. H. Solomon Freedom Consolidation Act of 2002 endorsed the vision of NATO enlargement expressed by Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton. At the Madrid Summit in 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO. The NATO heads of state and government declared their intention to invite more nations to join the alliance, emphasizing that no European democratic country fulfilling the treaty's objectives would be excluded from consideration. This commitment was reiterated at the Washington Summit in April 1999, where NATO pledged to continue welcoming new members who uphold the treaty's principles and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, several European countries declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement, emphasizing that the admission of one or more countries would benefit all. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all European democracies seeking security and freedom, emphasizing that no nation should be used as a pawn in the enlargement agenda. At the Prague Summit in November 2002, NATO expressed support for membership of all European democracies willing to uphold responsibilities, ensuring no automatic exclusions or veto power for non-NATO countries. Former President Clinton also emphasized NATO's openness to emerging democracies in Europe. In November 2002, Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia were invited to join NATO in the second round of enlargement. The US Senate approved the accession protocols for these countries on May 8, 2003. NATO's door remains open to European democracies willing to meet membership obligations. At the Istanbul Summit in June 2004, NATO reaffirmed its Open Door Policy and welcomed the progress of Albania, Croatia, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in implementing their Membership Action Plans. The door to NATO membership remains open for new members. NATO reaffirmed its Open Door Policy at the Istanbul Summit in June 2004, welcoming the progress of Albania, Croatia, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in implementing their Membership Action Plans. The organization will continue to assess each country's candidacy individually and review progress towards membership at the next Summit. Georgia has expressed its desire to join the Euro-Atlantic alliance. Georgia is actively seeking to join NATO, working closely with the organization and its members to meet membership criteria. President George W. Bush expressed support for Georgia's NATO membership during a press conference with President Mikhail Saakashvili in 2006. NATO Secretary General Jaap de Hoop reaffirmed the organization's Open Door Policy in 2006. In September 2006, NATO announced an Intensified Dialogue on membership with Georgia, contingent on their democratic, defense, and economic reforms. Congress calls for timely admission of Albania, Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia to NATO for security and stability in Europe. A NATO Summit will be held in Riga, Latvia in November 2006. SEC. 3. DECLARATIONS OF POLICY. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of NATO to include European democracies willing to meet the responsibilities of membership, as outlined in various summit declarations and acts. President George W. Bush and former President William J. Clinton have urged NATO allies to work with the United States in promoting global security. This includes supporting the enlargement of NATO to include qualified candidate states like Georgia, Albania, Croatia, and Macedonia. Designation of Albania, Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia as eligible for NATO assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Albania, Croatia, and Georgia designated as eligible for NATO assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The Republic of Macedonia is designated as eligible for NATO assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, along with Albania, Croatia, and Georgia. This designation is in addition to other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 designates Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Bulgaria, and Slovakia as eligible for assistance. The President can also designate other countries for assistance under the same Act. SEC. 5 authorizes security assistance for Albania, Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia under the Arms Export Control Act for fiscal year 2007. SEC. 6 expresses Congress's support for Ukraine's potential NATO membership. Passed the Senate on November 16, 2006. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
